utterance: DK: There's some evidence that um, you know, folks aren't so eager to jump industries even when there's opportunities to transition from carbon-rich industries to to renewable energy industries. And so I think we should be careful about the assumption that that uh, you know, just because we try to stand up new industries for carbon removal or or renewable energy that folks are going to be uh on board and wanting to do that. I think it will require a fair amount of incentives, you know, removing incentives and subsidies from fossil fuels and potentially standing them up on uh zero carbon or negative carbon uh industries to help that transition.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: DK mentions 'some evidence' to support the claim that people are not eager to switch industries, which strengthens the argument against the assumption that new industries will automatically attract workers.
annotations.express alternative decision: DK suggests being cautious about assuming people will readily transition to new industries, implying a rejection of the idea that simply creating new industries will solve the problem, and proposes the need for incentives to facilitate the transition.
annotations.expand on existing idea: DK expands on the idea of transitioning to renewable energy industries by adding details about the need for incentives and removing disincentives like fossil fuel subsidies to facilitate the transition.

annotations.propose decision: JB is suggesting a course of action, which is to remove people from their comfort zones to encourage them to try new things.

utterance: RA: As long as we're talking about the issues of of the more societal aspects of decarbonizing economy, which which I think we should would be a good idea to sort of decide whether or not that's something we we really want to tackle here or if it's more the technological or scientific aspects or to what degree they they connect in in a way that we could address meaningfully. But I just wanted to throw in that there are clearly social license aspects along the lines we've been talking about in terms of getting buy-in from society. But one that I've seen that I'm also concerned about uh and Julia uh articulated this well in a way I hadn't heard is the mitigation avoidance um uh protestation which actually I find to be common among scientists that we shouldn't even be thinking about these things because it is an avoidance of what we should be doing to uh reduce emissions in the first place. And at least in the scientific circles that I work in, I meet up with a lot of resistance to even seriously talking about many of the uh fascinating and important and inevitable inevitably necessary technologies and science that we're talking about. I'm not sure that that's something we want to focus on here, but it's just something that I I I find to be uh an obstacle uh in in the circles that I work in.

propose decision.Explanation: RA suggests that the group should decide whether to tackle the societal aspects of decarbonizing economy or focus on the technological/scientific aspects, or the degree to which they connect.

expand on existing idea.Explanation: RA expands on the discussion about societal aspects of decarbonizing by introducing the concept of 'social license' and 'mitigation avoidance' as obstacles.

utterance: GG: This was on the cows and poultry. So Roger and Simona, and I think going back to some of the things that Rafael talked about, I think this is a space which is ripe for hybrid technologies. I mean, oftentimes when we talk about negative emission technologies, we have those six or seven technologies in mind, which are, you know, backs or direct air capture or just enhanced weathering. And they're very discreet. And they're very discreet groups of people who actually work on these very discreet set of technologies. But the fact of the matter is that there are a lot of co-benefits and co-gen and, um, I would say synergies that can be obtained by coupling some of these. So for example, if we can come up with pathways for direct air capture and soils. There's a lot that we can learn from the fluid particle interactions, from the mineral and the fluid interactions by just studying, uh, engineered weathering and applying some of those concepts, uh, for direct air capture and soils through weathering, for example. Uh, there could be synergies in the way we use biochar, right? I mean, biochar, I guess the controversy there with biochar is that, you know, you take biomass from location A and put it in location B doesn't necessarily mean that there's been a significant carbon offset, but there could be more creative ways of using biochar so it can be used to maybe capture CO2. I don't know. So I, one way to think about this is to hybridize some of these technologies, hybridize some of these pathways to maybe get them, get us to start thinking about co-benefits. That could be one way. Uh, and again, uh, in the context of biogas, if there, if there are ways, and again, not a plug for what we're doing, but if there is a way for us to remove the CO2 that is co-produced with say the methane and biogas, mineralize that and produce a carbonate at the same time, that is an unconventional way of looking at bioenergy with carbon capture and removal. So there could be pathways in which we could combine weathering with some of these more engineered pathways and vice versa. I think that if there is going to be potential investment, I would encourage, uh, perhaps some of it to go towards some of these hybrid pathways and uncovering the underlying science so that way there is a thermodynamic basis and there is a kinetic basis for these pathways going forward.

acknowledge contribution.Explanation: The speaker acknowledges the previous discussion about cows and poultry, referencing Roger and Simona.

expand on existing idea.Explanation: The speaker builds upon Rafael's points by suggesting that the field is ripe for hybrid technologies, elaborating on the potential synergies between different negative emission technologies like direct air capture and soils.

present new idea.Explanation: The speaker introduces the novel concept of hybridizing negative emission technologies to achieve co-benefits, suggesting combining direct air capture with soils and exploring creative uses of biochar.

encourage participation.Explanation: The speaker encourages investment in hybrid pathways and uncovering the underlying science, suggesting a direction for future research and development.

Um, you know, one of my other hats, I work with farmers with our dairy manure waste problem in Wisconsin. You know, and they're always looking for economic pathways. So a lot of them will anaerobically digest their manure and then they're trying to come up with co-products that they can sell that it's great if they're environmentally beneficial. But I mean, they're focused on the economics. Really, if we, going back to Greeshma's point, you know, if we start thinking about adding some of these technologies together, I think that's where you'll see the synergistic benefits. utterance: RS: Yeah, one thing I can sort of add to the carbon tech story that we were talking at the beginning is that we have the person who wants to buy the carbon credit, then we have the person doing the sequestration, then we have the market, which is doing the financial transaction. But then we also have the third party verification. Right? So the third party verification needs to have experimental methodologies or simulation software or lifecycle analysis tools to verify that everything that is going on in that in that circle is is actually true. So and and that's something that we need a lot of. I'm I'm part of the peer review board member of Nori, which is the carbon market that's most active right now in the US. And what they are relying currently on is something called, I think it's called Comet. Right? So it's a software that simulates if you do this and this and this to your soil, this will be how much carbon you're sequestering. So it's based on a lot of assumptions and it's based on, yeah, a huge amount of uncertainty. But that's the best they have right now. So that's what they're relying on. But I see that this space needs to grow a lot. So you need much better tools, much better. So that's both experimental and and modeling and predictive tools to really verify that what's going on is actually true.
